trans-unit.source: <properties pageTitle="Customize Swashbuckle-generated API definitions" description="Learn how to customize Swagger API definitions that are generated by Swashbuckle for an API app in Azure App Service." services="app-service\api" documentationCenter=".net" authors="bradygaster" manager="wpickett" editor="jimbe"/>
trans-unit.target: <properties pageTitle="Customize Swashbuckle-generated API definitions" description="Learn how to customize Swagger API definitions that are generated by Swashbuckle for an API app in Azure App Service." services="app-service\api" documentationCenter=".net" authors="bradygaster" manager="wpickett" editor="jimbe"/>

trans-unit.source: <tags ms.service="app-service-api" ms.workload="web" ms.tgt_pltfrm="dotnet" ms.devlang="na" ms.topic="article" ms.date="08/16/2015" ms.author="bradyg"/>
trans-unit.target: <tags ms.service="app-service-api" ms.workload="web" ms.tgt_pltfrm="dotnet" ms.devlang="na" ms.topic="article" ms.date="08/16/2015" ms.author="bradyg"/>

trans-unit.source: This article explains how to customize Swashbuckle to handle common scenarios where you may want to alter the default behavior:
trans-unit.target: This article explains how to customize Swashbuckle to handle common scenarios where you may want to alter the default behavior:

trans-unit.source: Swashbuckle generates duplicate operation identifiers for overloads of controller methods
trans-unit.target: Swashbuckle generates duplicate operation identifiers for overloads of controller methods

trans-unit.source: Swashbuckle assumes that the only valid response from a method is HTTP 200 (OK)
trans-unit.target: Swashbuckle assumes that the only valid response from a method is HTTP 200 (OK)

trans-unit.source: Swashbuckle generates Swagger operation identifiers by concatenating controller name and method name.
trans-unit.target: Swashbuckle generates Swagger operation identifiers by concatenating controller name and method name.

trans-unit.source: This pattern creates a problem when you have multiple overloads of a method: Swashbuckle generates duplicate operation ids, which is invalid Swagger JSON.
trans-unit.target: This pattern creates a problem when you have multiple overloads of a method: Swashbuckle generates duplicate operation ids, which is invalid Swagger JSON.

trans-unit.source: For example, the following controller code causes Swashbuckle to generate three Contact_Get operation ids.
trans-unit.target: For example, the following controller code causes Swashbuckle to generate three Contact_Get operation ids.

trans-unit.source: You can solve the problem manually by giving the methods unique names, such as the following for this example:
trans-unit.target: You can solve the problem manually by giving the methods unique names, such as the following for this example:

trans-unit.source: Get
trans-unit.target: Get

trans-unit.source: GetById
trans-unit.target: GetById

trans-unit.source: GetPage
trans-unit.target: GetPage

trans-unit.source: The alternative is to extend Swashbuckle to make it automatically generate unique operation ids.
trans-unit.target: The alternative is to extend Swashbuckle to make it automatically generate unique operation ids.

trans-unit.source: The following steps show how to customize Swashbuckle by using the SwaggerConfig.cs file that is included in the project by the Visual Studio API Apps Preview project template.
trans-unit.target: The following steps show how to customize Swashbuckle by using the SwaggerConfig.cs file that is included in the project by the Visual Studio API Apps Preview project template.

trans-unit.source: You can also customize Swashbuckle in a Web API project that you configure for deployment as an API app.
trans-unit.target: You can also customize Swashbuckle in a Web API project that you configure for deployment as an API app.

trans-unit.source: Create a custom IOperationFilter implementation
trans-unit.target: Create a custom IOperationFilter implementation

trans-unit.source: The IOperationFilter interface provides an extensibility point for Swashbuckle users who want to customize various aspects of the Swagger metadata process.
trans-unit.target: The IOperationFilter interface provides an extensibility point for Swashbuckle users who want to customize various aspects of the Swagger metadata process.

trans-unit.source: The following code demonstrates one method of changing the operation-id-generation behavior.
trans-unit.target: The following code demonstrates one method of changing the operation-id-generation behavior.

trans-unit.source: The code appends parameter names to the operation id name.
trans-unit.target: The code appends parameter names to the operation id name.

trans-unit.source: In App_Start\SwaggerConfig.cs file, call the OperationFilter method to cause Swashbuckle to use the new IOperationFilter implementation.
trans-unit.target: In App_Start\SwaggerConfig.cs file, call the OperationFilter method to cause Swashbuckle to use the new IOperationFilter implementation.

trans-unit.source: The SwaggerConfig.cs file that is dropped in by the Swashbuckle NuGet package contains many commented-out examples of extensibility points.
trans-unit.target: The SwaggerConfig.cs file that is dropped in by the Swashbuckle NuGet package contains many commented-out examples of extensibility points.

trans-unit.source: The additional comments are not shown here.
trans-unit.target: The additional comments are not shown here.

trans-unit.source: After you make this change, your IOperationFilter implementation is used and causes unique operation ids to be generated.
trans-unit.target: After you make this change, your IOperationFilter implementation is used and causes unique operation ids to be generated.

trans-unit.source: By default, Swashbuckle assumes that an HTTP 200 (OK) response is the only legitimate response from a Web API method.
trans-unit.target: By default, Swashbuckle assumes that an HTTP 200 (OK) response is the only legitimate response from a Web API method.

trans-unit.source: In some cases, you may want to return other response codes without causing the client to raise an exception.
trans-unit.target: In some cases, you may want to return other response codes without causing the client to raise an exception.

trans-unit.source: For example, the following Web API code demonstrates a scenario in which you would want the client to accept either a 200 or a 404 as valid responses.
trans-unit.target: For example, the following Web API code demonstrates a scenario in which you would want the client to accept either a 200 or a 404 as valid responses.

trans-unit.source: In this scenario, the Swagger that Swashbuckle generates by default specifies only one legitimate HTTP status code, HTTP 200.
trans-unit.target: In this scenario, the Swagger that Swashbuckle generates by default specifies only one legitimate HTTP status code, HTTP 200.

trans-unit.source: Since Visual Studio uses the Swagger API definition to generate code for the client, it creates client code that raises an exception for any response other than an HTTP 200.
trans-unit.target: Since Visual Studio uses the Swagger API definition to generate code for the client, it creates client code that raises an exception for any response other than an HTTP 200.

trans-unit.source: The code below is from a C# client generated for this sample Web API method.
trans-unit.target: The code below is from a C# client generated for this sample Web API method.

trans-unit.source: Swashbuckle provides two ways of customizing the list of expected HTTP response codes that it generates, using XML comments or the SwaggerResponse attribute.
trans-unit.target: Swashbuckle provides two ways of customizing the list of expected HTTP response codes that it generates, using XML comments or the SwaggerResponse attribute.

trans-unit.source: The attribute is easier, but it is only available in Swashbuckle 5.1.5 or later.
trans-unit.target: The attribute is easier, but it is only available in Swashbuckle 5.1.5 or later.

trans-unit.source: The API Apps preview new-project template in Visual Studio 2013 includes Swashbuckle version 5.0.0, so if you used the template and don't want to update Swashbuckle, your only option is to use XML comments.
trans-unit.target: The API Apps preview new-project template in Visual Studio 2013 includes Swashbuckle version 5.0.0, so if you used the template and don't want to update Swashbuckle, your only option is to use XML comments.

trans-unit.source: Use this method to specify response codes if your Swashbuckle version is earlier than 5.1.5.
trans-unit.target: Use this method to specify response codes if your Swashbuckle version is earlier than 5.1.5.

trans-unit.source: First, add XML documentation comments over the methods you wish to specify HTTP response codes for.
trans-unit.target: First, add XML documentation comments over the methods you wish to specify HTTP response codes for.

trans-unit.source: Taking the sample Web API action shown above and applying the XML documentation to it would result in code like the following example.
trans-unit.target: Taking the sample Web API action shown above and applying the XML documentation to it would result in code like the following example.

trans-unit.source: Add instructions in the SwaggerConfig.cs file to direct Swashbuckle to make use of the XML documentation file.
trans-unit.target: Add instructions in the SwaggerConfig.cs file to direct Swashbuckle to make use of the XML documentation file.

trans-unit.source: Open SwaggerConfig.cs and create a method on the SwaggerConfig class to specify the path to the documentation XML file.
trans-unit.target: Open SwaggerConfig.cs and create a method on the SwaggerConfig class to specify the path to the documentation XML file.

trans-unit.source: Scroll down in the SwaggerConfig.cs file until you see the commented-out line of code resembling the screen shot below.
trans-unit.target: Scroll down in the SwaggerConfig.cs file until you see the commented-out line of code resembling the screen shot below.

trans-unit.source: Uncomment the line to enable the XML comments processing during Swagger generation.
trans-unit.target: Uncomment the line to enable the XML comments processing during Swagger generation.

trans-unit.source: In order to generate the XML documentation file, go into the project's properties and enable the XML documentation file as shown in the screenshot below.
trans-unit.target: In order to generate the XML documentation file, go into the project's properties and enable the XML documentation file as shown in the screenshot below.

trans-unit.source: Once you perform these steps, the Swagger JSON generated by Swashbuckle will reflect the HTTP response codes that you specified in the XML comments.
trans-unit.target: Once you perform these steps, the Swagger JSON generated by Swashbuckle will reflect the HTTP response codes that you specified in the XML comments.

trans-unit.source: The screenshot below demonstrates this new JSON payload.
trans-unit.target: The screenshot below demonstrates this new JSON payload.

trans-unit.source: When you use Visual Studio to regenerate the client code for your REST API, the C# code accepts both the HTTP OK and Not Found status codes without raising an exception, allowing your consuming code to make decisions on how to handle the return of a null Contact record.
trans-unit.target: When you use Visual Studio to regenerate the client code for your REST API, the C# code accepts both the HTTP OK and Not Found status codes without raising an exception, allowing your consuming code to make decisions on how to handle the return of a null Contact record.

trans-unit.source: The code for this demonstration can be found in <linkText>this GitHub repository</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: The code for this demonstration can be found in <linkText>this GitHub repository</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Along with the Web API project marked up with XML documentation comments is a Console Application project that contains a generated client for this API.
trans-unit.target: Along with the Web API project marked up with XML documentation comments is a Console Application project that contains a generated client for this API.

trans-unit.source: The <linkText>SwaggerResponse</linkText><title></title> attribute is available in Swashbuckle 5.1.5 and later.
trans-unit.target: The <linkText>SwaggerResponse</linkText><title></title> attribute is available in Swashbuckle 5.1.5 and later.

trans-unit.source: In case you have an earlier version in your project, this section starts by explaining how to update the Swashbuckle NuGet package so that you can use this attribute.
trans-unit.target: In case you have an earlier version in your project, this section starts by explaining how to update the Swashbuckle NuGet package so that you can use this attribute.

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, right-click your Web API project and click Manage NuGet Packages.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, right-click your Web API project and click Manage NuGet Packages.

trans-unit.source: Click the Update button next to the Swashbuckle NuGet package.
trans-unit.target: Click the Update button next to the Swashbuckle NuGet package.

trans-unit.source: Add the SwaggerResponse attributes to the Web API action methods for which you want to specify valid HTTP response codes.
trans-unit.target: Add the SwaggerResponse attributes to the Web API action methods for which you want to specify valid HTTP response codes.

trans-unit.source: Add a using statement for the attribute's namespace:
trans-unit.target: Add a using statement for the attribute's namespace:

trans-unit.source: Browse to the /swagger/docs/v1 URL of your project and the various HTTP response codes will be visible in the Swagger JSON.
trans-unit.target: Browse to the /swagger/docs/v1 URL of your project and the various HTTP response codes will be visible in the Swagger JSON.

trans-unit.source: The code for this demonstration can be found in <linkText>this GitHub repository</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: The code for this demonstration can be found in <linkText>this GitHub repository</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Along with the Web API project decorated with the SwaggerResponse attribute is a Console Application project that contains a generated client for this API.
trans-unit.target: Along with the Web API project decorated with the SwaggerResponse attribute is a Console Application project that contains a generated client for this API.

trans-unit.source: This article has shown how to customize the way Swashbuckle generates operation ids and valid response codes.
trans-unit.target: This article has shown how to customize the way Swashbuckle generates operation ids and valid response codes.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <linkText>Swashbuckle on GitHub</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <linkText>Swashbuckle on GitHub</linkText><title></title>.
